Stem: Green with covering of minute star-shaped hairs, and with scattered stout straw coloured prickles about 1.5 cm long.
Leaves: Alternately arranged along stems with short stalks, bright green, covered with minute star shaped hairs, deeply lobed and with numerous prickles.
Flowers: Typical Solanum flowers, purplish blue in clusters of 3-6 towards the end of branches between the leaves, prickles on supporting leaves.
FruitSeeds: Globular, bright yellow when ripe then turning brown or black, to 3 cm diameter, fleshy or juicy, tomato like, drying with age.
Habitat: Roadsides, urban bushland, waste areas, neglected land.
DistinguishingFeatures: Similar in appearance to Narrawa Burr, but no pale leaf underside, and fruits turn brown with age.
Impacts: Restricts stock movement, unpalatable, outcompetes native species.
